tool.name: Meta-Analysis
tool.description: approach with a fixed effect model for untargeted metabolomics
tool.command: meta_analysis.py --wide $input --design $design --uniqID $uniqID --study $study --treatment "$treatment" --contrast $contrast #if $forest --forest #end if ##Default is set to only use Fixed-effect model, use standard mean difference for effect size, and unbiased estimation for cmMethod --model "FE" --effectSize "SMD" --cmMethod "UB" --summary $summary --report $report

param.name: input
param.label: Wide Dataset
param.help: Input your tab-separated wide format dataset. If file is not tab-separated see TIP below.

param.name: design
param.label: Design File
param.help: Input your design file (tab-separated). Note you need a 'sampleID' column. If not tab separated see TIP below.

param.name: uniqID
param.label: Unique FeatureID
param.help: Name of the column in your wide dataset that contains unique feature identifiers.

param.name: study
param.label: Batch
param.help: Name of the column in your design file that contains batch/study information.

param.name: treatment
param.label: Variable Column
param.help: Name of the column in your design file that contains the name of the variables to be contrasted.

param.name: contrast
param.label: Variables to be compared
param.help: Enter the name of the variables to be compared (comma separated, no spaces)

param.name: forest
param.label: Output Forest Plot
param.help: If 'Yes', the Meta-analysis program will output a forest plot

tool.help:
@TIP_AND_WARNING@
**Tool Description**
Metabolomics experiments have variations in sample acquisition, extraction, and data acquisition (Gouveia et al., 2021) with many large-scale experiments subdividing the samples into smaller batches of samples.
This meta-analysis tool uses metafor (Meta-Analysis Package for R (Viechtbauer, 2010) to calculate batch-level summary statistics and model estimates. We note that the version wrapped here has been tested using the standardized mean difference (SMD) to estimate the effect size, unbiased estimates of the sampling variance (UB) and a fixed effects (FE) model.
Gouveia, G., et al. (2021). Long-Term Metabolomics Reference Material. bioRxiv. https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.03.24.436834
More details about the Metafor package can be found here:
Viechtbauer, W. (2010). Conducting meta-analyses in R with the metafor package. Journal of Statistical Software, 36(3), 1-48. https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v036.i03
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
**Input**
- Two input datasets are required.
@WIDE@
**NOTE:** The sampleIDs must match the sampleIDs in the Design File (below). Extra columns will automatically be ignored.
@METADATA@
@UNIQID@
**Batch** - Enter the name of the column in the design file that contains the batch information for each sample.
**Variable Column**
- Enter the name of the column in the design file that contains the name of the variables to be contrasted.
**Contrast**
- Enter the name of the variables that you want to compare (these should be in the 'Variable Column'). Each variable should be comma separated, no spaces. - Meta-analyis for each feature to compare test samples to control samples: list name of the test sample followed by name of the control sample. - Meta-analysis to test whether a feature is differentially expressed in a group of test samples compared to control: list name of all test samples followed by control sample.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
**Output**
This tool outputs two TSV files and an optional PDF of a forest plot:
(1) a summary TSV file that contains the statistical metrics of the batch effect with the following columns:
- featureID - effect - calculated effect size (Standard Mean Difference between the experimental and control treatments) - se - standard errors of the coefficients - z_value - test statistics of the coefficients - p_value - p-values for test statistics - ci_low - lower bound of confidence intervals - ci_upper - upper bound of confidence intervals
(2) a report file that contains a description of how much variability and heterogeneity has been calculated for each sample, and what the results of the fixed effects model were.
(3) a pdf containing a forest plots for all features in the wide dataset.
